s.gd: Choisich Alasdair tron chladh le a cheann crom.
s.en: Alexander walked through the graveyard with his head bowed.

s.gd: Ràinig e a’ chlach a bha e ri lorg.
s.en: He reached the stone that he was looking for.

s.gd: Cha robh e air a faicinn a-riamh, ach dh’ innis an sgrìobhadh a bh’oirre dhà an rud a bha e ag iarraidh fhaighinn a-mach.
s.en: He had never seen it, but the writing that was on it told him the thing that he wanted to find out.

s.gd: Choimhead e rithe a-rithist.
s.en: He looked at it again.

s.gd: “Fionnlagh Dòmhnallach, 1940, deich bliadhna fichead a dh’aois.”
s.en: “Finlay MacDonald, 1940, thirty years old.”

s.gd: Cha tàinig deur gu a shùil.
s.en: No tear cames to his eye.

s.gd: Ruith coinean seachad mu a chasan.
s.en: A rabbit ran past his feet.

s.gd: Chuimhnich e air a mhàthair ann an Canada; bha i airson faighinn cho fada air falbh agus a b’urrainn di às dèidh na deuchainn a thàinig na beatha òig.
s.en: He remembered his mother in Canada; she had wanted to get as far away as possible after the test that had come into her young life.

s.gd: Cha robh i ach fichead bliadhna agus a ceithir aig an àm.
s.en: She had only been twenty four years old at the time.

s.gd: Bha Fionnlagh agus i-fhèin air ceithir bliadhna shona a chur seachad còmla ri chèile, agus anns na dhà mu dheireadh bha a cupan sòlais làn nuair chaidh mac a bhreith dhaibh.
s.en: Finlay and herself had spent four happy years together, and in the last two her cup of solace was full when a son was born to them.

s.gd: “Siud mar nach robh i an-diugh,” smaoinich Alasdair.
s.en: “That as she isn’t today,” thought Alexander.

s.gd: Thòisich e a’ beachdachadh air na nithean a dh’fhaodadh a bhith aca mur a biodh gòraich athar — ’se gòraich a bh’ann na bheachd-san co-dhiù.
s.en: He started thinking on the things that they could have had, were it not for his father’s foolishness – it was foolishness in his opinion anyway.

s.gd: Bha fios aige gur ann an aghaidh a càlach a dh’fhalbh a mhàthair a Chanada leis-san.
s.en: He knew that it was against her wishes that his mother left for Canada with him.

s.gd: Thionndaidh e a chùlaibh ris a’ chloich.
s.en: He turned his back on the stone.

s.gd: Bha i a’ toirt droch smuain a-steach air.
s.en: It was taking a bad thought into him.

s.gd: Airson mionaid thàinig fuath uabhasach na chridhe airson athar, airson an rud a rinn e, ged nach robh cuimhne aigesan air ach mar a chaidh innse dha.
s.en: For a minute a terrible anger for his father came into his heart, for the thing that he had done, even though he had no memory of him except for what he had been told.

s.gd: Dhùin e a shùilean.
s.en: He closed his eyes.

s.gd: Chunnaic e, mar gum b’ann, a mhàthair na suidhe air beulaibh an teine ann an Canada, agus e-fhèin na h-uchd.
s.en: He saw, as if he were there, his mother sat in front of the fire in Canada, and himself in her lap.

s.gd: Bha cuimhne aige fhathast facal air an fhacal mar thubhairt i ris.
s.en: He remembered still word by word as she had said to him.

s.gd: “Càite,” ars esan rithe, “bheil m’athair-sa?”
s.en: “Where,” he said to her, “is my own father?”

s.gd: “Tha,” fhreagair ise, “d’athair air a thiodhlaiceadh ann an Cladh a’ Ghlinne am baile Ardanais.
s.en: “Your father,” she replied, “is burried in the Glen Cemetary in the town of Ardanish.”

s.gd: Chuir e roimhe,” thubhairt i, “gu snàmhadh e na bu luaithe na neach eile bho Aird nan Sgeir gu taobh thall Mol nam Muc.
s.en: He decided,” she said, “that he would swim faster than anyone else from Aird nan Sgeir to the far side of Mol nan Muc.

s.gd: Bha e riamh math air an t-snàmh, ach an dèidh sin bha eagal orm; faodaidh a’ mhuir làmh an uachdair fhaighinn gu math aithghearr.
s.en: He had always been good at swimming, but after that I was afraid; the sea can get the upper hand very soon.

s.gd: An là ud dh’iarr e gum bithinn fhìn agus tu-fhèin ga choimhead agus dh’fhalbh sinn nar dithis, agus nuair ràinig sinn bha esan letheach-slighe, agus bàta beag ga fheitheamh anns an fhasgadh air an taobh thall.
s.en: That day, he asked that I myself and yourself would be watching him and we left together, and when we arrived he was halfway across, and a little boat waiting for him in the shelter on the other side.

s.gd: Dìreach mus do ràinig e am bàta chaidh e às mo shealladh, agus chan fhaca mi tuilleadh e gus an tug luchd a’ bhàta a-steach e marbh.”
s.en: Just before he reached the boat he went out of my sight, and I did not see him again until the boat people brought him out dead.”

s.gd: Chuimhnich e an seo mar bhris a mhàthair sìos, a bhochdainn a bha fios aige a dh’fhuiling i, oir cha robh e-fhèin ach dà bhliadhna, agus cha b’urrainn dhi a dhol a-mach a dh’obair.
s.en: He remembered here how his mother had broken down, the poverty that he knew she had suffered, because he himself was only two years old, and she could not go out to work.

s.gd: Chuala e glaodhaich eun fad às gus ghoirisich e.
s.en: He heard a bird calling far away until he shuddered.

s.gd: Thug e sùil eile air a’ chloich, choisich e air adhart, gus dhùin e an geata às a dhèidh.
s.en: He took another look at the stone, he walked on, until he closed the gate behind him.

s.gd: Sheas Anna, màthair Alasdair, aig an uinneig.
s.en: Anna, Alexander’s mother, stood at the window.

s.gd: Bha còrr agus fichead bliadhna a-nis bho thàinig i a Chanada.
s.en: It was more than twenty years now since she had come to Canada.

s.gd: Tharraing i an cùirtear agus chuir i air an solas.
s.en: She drew the curtain and she put on the light.

s.gd: Bha i ag ionndrain Alasdair; cha robh i cleachdte ri bhith na h-aonar.
s.en: She was missing Alexander; she was not used to being on her own.

s.gd: ’S ann glè mhì-rianail a bha i na h-inntinn nuair dh’innis Alasdair dhi gu robh e dol a thoirt sgrìob a dh’Ardanais a dh’fhaicinn an àite anns an d’rugadh e.
s.en: She had been very confused in her mind when Alexander had told her that he was going to take a trip to Ardanish to see the place where he had been born.

s.gd: Bha fios aice nach robh e ag innse na fìrinn, nach b’e idir baile Ardanais a bha e airson fhaicinn, ach Aird nan Sgeir, agus Mol nam Muc agus is dòcha uaigh athar.
s.en: She knew that he was not telling the truth, that it was not at all the town of Ardanish that he wanted to see, but Aird nan Sgeir, and Mol nam Muc and perhaps his father’s grave.

s.gd: Leum an cat beag geal na h-uchd.
s.en: The little white cat jumped into her lap.

s.gd: Shlìob i a dhruim.
s.en: She stroked his back.

s.gd: Smaoinich i a-rithist air Alasdair, agus thàinig na teagamhan gu beulaibh a h-inntinn.
s.en: She thought again about Alexander, and the doubts came to the front of her mind.

s.gd: Bha eagal oirre gum biodh beagan de thàladh na mara na fhuil, agus cha robh fios aice gu dè a’ bhuaidh a bhiodh aig baile a bhreith air.
s.en: She was afraid that there would be a little of the lullaby of the sea in his blood, and she did not know what effect the town of his birth would have on him.

s.gd: ’S iongantach mur biodh iomadh atharrachadh ann.
s.en: It would be surprising if there would not be many a change there.

s.gd: ’S iomadh rud a bheireadh fichead bliadhna mun cuairt.
s.en: Twenty years would have shifted around many a thing.

s.gd: Thòisich an cat ri mialaich.
s.en: The cat started to mew.

s.gd: Leig i a-mach air an doras e.
s.en: She put him outside by the door.
